scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, of number four, Privet Drive, were proud to say that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much.
I'm going to work, dear.
Don't forget to pick up some milk on your way home.
They were the last people you'd expect to be involved in anything strange or mysterious, because they just didn't hold with such nonsense.
Dudley, eat your breakfast!
I don't wanna!

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: Mr. Dursley hummed as he picked out his most boring tie for work, and Mrs. Dursley gossiped away happily as she wrestled a screaming Dudley into his high chair.
Did you hear about the Jones' new car?
No, what's so special about it?
It's got four wheels and an engine, just like all the others!
None of them noticed a large, tawny owl flutter past the window.
I'm off to work, dear.

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: Mr. Dursley got into his car and backed out of number four's drive.
Little tyke.
As he drove around the corner and up the road, he watched the cat in his mirror.
It was now reading the sign that said Privet Drive -- no, looking at the sign; cats couldn't read maps or signs.
What could he have been thinking of? It must have been a trick of the light.

scene.background: A busy street in the town, with people walking in all directions. There are shops and buildings on either side of the road, with cars driving by.

dialogues.dialogue: As he sat in the usual morning traffic jam, he couldn't help noticing that there seemed to be a lot of strangely dressed people about.
What's with all these weirdos?
People in cloaks. Mr. Dursley couldn't bear people who dressed in funny clothes -- the getups you saw on young people!
The nerve of him!
But then it struck Mr. Dursley that this was probably some silly stunt -- these people were obviously collecting for something...

scene.background: The Grunnings parking lot, with cars parked in rows and a building in the background.

dialogues.dialogue: The traffic moved on and a few minutes later, Mr. Dursley arrived in the Grunnings parking lot, his mind back on drills.
Ah, finally. Now to get that large order of drills.
He got out of the car and walked towards the building, already thinking about his day ahead.
I hope that order comes through today.
He pushed open the door and walked into the building, leaving the strange sights of the morning behind.

scene.background: An office on the ninth floor with a large window, a desk, and a chair. The room is ordinary and tidy, with a hint of corporate atmosphere.

dialogues.dialogue: Mr. Dursley always sat with his back to the window in his office on the ninth floor.
Yell at five different people.
He made several important telephone calls and shouted a bit more.
I'll stretch my legs and walk across the road to buy myself a bun from the bakery.
He'd forgotten all about the people in cloaks until he passed a group of them next to the baker's.

scene.background: A street with a bakery, people walking by, and a group of people in cloaks whispering excitedly.

dialogues.dialogue: He eyed them angrily as he passed.
The Potters, that's right, that's what I heard yes, their son, Harry.
Harry?
Mr. Dursley stopped dead. Fear flooded him.
No, no, it can't be...

scene.background: Mr. Dursley's office, with a telephone on the desk and a secretary outside.

dialogues.dialogue: Not now, I'm busy.
He seized his telephone, and had almost finished dialing his home number when he changed his mind.
No, no, it's nothing.
He put the receiver back down and stroked his mustache, thinking...
Potter isn't such an unusual name. He was sure there were lots of people called Potter who had a son called Harry.

scene.background: A busy street outside a building, with people walking in and out. The atmosphere is normal and everyday.

dialogues.dialogue: lot harder to concentrate on drills that afternoon and when he left the building at five o'clock, he was still so worried that
Sorry,
Don't be sorry, my dear sir, for nothing could upset me today! Rejoice, for You-Know-Who has gone at last! Even Muggles like yourself should be celebrating, this happy, happy day!
He had been hugged by a complete stranger. He also thought he had been called a Muggle, whatever that was.

scene.background: A driveway of a suburban house, with a garden wall and a tabby cat sitting on it. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: Shoo!
The cat didn't move. It just gave him a stern look. Was this normal cat behavior?

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: I told him over dinner all about Mrs. Next Door's problems with her daughter and how Dudley had learned a new word ("Won't!").
Mr. Dursley tried to act normally.

scene.background: A TV news studio, with a news anchor sitting at a desk. The atmosphere is professional and informative.

dialogues.dialogue: And finally, bird-watchers everywhere have reported that the nation's owls have been behaving very unusually today.

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: "ormally hunt at night and are hardly ever seen in daylight, there have been hundreds of sightings of these birds flying in every direction since sunrise."
"Most mysterious. And now, over to Jim McGuffin with the weather. Going to be any more showers of owls tonight, Jim?"

"Well, Ted, I don't know about that, but it's not only the owls that have been acting oddly today. Viewers as far apart as Kent, Yorkshire, and Dundee have been phoning in to tell me that instead of the rain I promised yesterday, they've had a downpour of shooting stars! Perhaps people have been celebrating Bonfire Night early -- it's not until next week, folks! But I can promise a wet night tonight."
"Er -- Petunia, dear -- you haven't heard from your sister lately, have you?"
"No. Why?"
"Funny stuff on the news. Owls... shooting stars... and there were a lot of funny-looking people in town today..."
"So?"
"Well, I just thought... maybe... it was something to do with... you know... her crowd."
"I suppose so."
"Their son -- he'd be about Dudley's age now, wouldn't he?"
"Harry. Nasty, common name, if you ask me."

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: ley, his heart sinking horribly. "Yes, I quite agree."
He didn't say another word on the subject as they went upstairs to bed.
While Mrs. Dursley was in the bathroom, Mr. Dursley crept to the bedroom window and peered down into the front garden.
The cat was still there. It was staring down Privet Drive as though it were waiting for something.
Was he imagining things? Could all this have anything to do with the Potters?
If it did... if it got out that they were related to a pair of-- well, he didn't think he could bear it.

scene.background: A bedroom with a bed, a window, and a bathroom door. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: The Dursleys got into bed. Mrs. Dursley fell asleep quickly but Mr. Dursley lay awake, turning it all over in his mind.
His last, comforting thought before he fell asleep was that even if the Potters were involved, there was no reason for them to come near him and Mrs. Dursley.
The Potters knew very well what he and Petunia thought about them and their kind....
He couldn't see how he and Petunia could get mixed up in anything that might be going on -- he yawned and turned over-- it couldn't affect them....
How very wrong he was.

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: Mr. Dursley might have been drifting into an uneasy sleep, but the cat on the wall outside was showing no sign of sleepiness.
It was sitting as still as a statue, its eyes fixed unblinkingly on the far corner of Privet Drive.
It didn't so much as quiver when a car door slammed on the next street, nor when two owls swooped overhead.
In fact, it was nearly midnight before the cat moved at all.
A man appeared on the corner the cat had been watching, appeared so suddenly and silently you'd have thought he'd just popped out of the ground.

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: The cat's tail twitched and its eyes narrowed.
Nothing like this man had ever been seen on Privet Drive.
He was tall, thin, and very old, judging by the silver of his hair and beard, which were both long enough to tuck into his belt.
He was wearing long robes, a purple cloak that swept the ground, and high-heeled, buckled boots.
His blue eyes were light, bright, and sparkling behind half-moon spectacles and his nose was very long and crooked, as though...

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: It had been broken at least twice. This man's name was Albus Dumbledore.
Albus Dumbledore didn't seem to realize that he had just arrived in a street where everything from his name to his boots was unwelcome.
I should have known.
He found what he was looking for in his inside pocket. It seemed to be a silver cigarette lighter.
He flicked it open, held it up in the air, and clicked it. The nearest street lamp went out with a little pop.
Fancy seeing you here, Professor McGonagall.
How did you know it was me?
My dear Professor, I've never seen a cat sit so stiffly.
You'd be stiff if you'd been sitting on a brick wall all day.

scene.background: The same quiet suburban street, but now with only two tiny pinpricks of light in the distance, which are the eyes of the cat watching Albus Dumbledore.

dialogues.dialogue: The only lights left on the whole street were two tiny pinpricks in the distance, which were the eyes of the cat watching him.
All day? When you could have been celebrating? I must have passed a dozen feasts and parties on my way here.
Oh yes, everyone...

scene.background: The Dursleys' dark living room, with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: "Ne's celebrating, all right," she said impatiently. "You'd think they'd be a bit more careful, but no -- even the Muggles have noticed something's going on. It was on their news."

"I heard it. Flocks of owls... shooting stars.... Well, they're not completely stupid. They were bound to notice something. Shooting stars down in Kent -- I'll bet that was Dedalus Diggle. He never had much sense."
"You can't blame them," said Dumbledore gently. "We've had precious little to celebrate for eleven years."

"I know that," said Professor McGonagall irritably. "But that's no reason to lose our heads. People are being downright careless, out on the streets in broad daylight, not even dressed in Muggle clothes, swapping rumors."
"Afine thing it would be if, on the very day You-Know-Who seems to have disappeared at last, the Muggles found out about us all. I suppose he really has gone, Dumbledore?"
"It certainly seems so," said Dumbledore. "We have much to be thankful for. Would you care for a lemon drop?"
"A what?"
"A lemon drop. They're a kind of Muggle sweet I'm rather fond of."
"No, thank you," said Professor McGonagall coldly, as though she didn't think this was the moment for lemon drops.
"As I say, even if You-Know-Who has gone -"

"My dear Professor, surely a sensible person like yourself can call him by his name? All this 'You-Know-Who' nonsense -- for eleven years I have been trying to persuade people to call him by his proper name: Voldemort."
"I know you haven't, said Professor McGonagall, sounding half exasperated, half admiring. "But you're different. Everyone knows you're the only one You-K

scene.background: A cold, dark, and eerie night in Godric's Hollow, with mist swirling around the streets and the sound of owls hooting in the distance. The atmosphere is tense and foreboding.

dialogues.dialogue: "You flatter me,"
"Voldemort had powers I will never have."
"Only because you're too -- well -- noble to use them."
"It's lucky it's dark. I haven't blushed so much since Madam Pomfrey told me she liked my new earmuffs."
"The owls are nothing next to the rumors that are flying around. You know what everyone's saying? About why he's disappeared? About what finally stopped him?"
"What they're saying is that last night Voldemort turned up in Godric's Hollow. He went to find the Potters. The rumor is that Lily and James Potter are -- are -- that they're -- dead."
"I know... I know..."

"That's not all. They're saying he tried to kill the Potter's son, Harry. But -- he couldn't. He couldn't kill that little boy. No one knows why, or how, but they're saying that when he couldn't kill Harry Potter, Voldemort's power somehow broke -- and that's why he's gone."
"We can only guess."

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: "Hagrid's late. I suppose it was he who told you I'd be here, by the way?"
"Yes,"
"And I don't suppose you're going to tell me why you're here, of all places?"
"I've come to bring Harry to his aunt and uncle. They're the only family he has left now."
"You don't mean -- you can't mean the people who live here?"

"Dumbledore -- you can't. I've been watching them all day. You couldn't find two people who are less like us. And they've got this son -- I saw him kicking his mother all the way up the street, screaming for sweets. Harry Potter come and live here!"

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: "Of course. But how is the boy getting here, Dumbledore?"
"You think it -- wise -- to trust Hagrid with something as important as this?"
"I would trust Hagrid with my life."
"I'm not saying his heart isn't in the right place,"
"but you can't pretend he's not careless. He does tend to -- what was that?"
"Hagrid."
"At last. And where did you get that motorcycle?"
"Borrowed it, Professor Dumbledore, sir."
"Young Sirius Black lent it to me. I've got him, sir."
"No problems, were there?"
"No, sir -- house was almost destroyed, but I got him out all right before the Muggles started swarmin' around."
"He fell asleep as we was flyin' over Bristol."
"Is that where -?"
"He'll have that scar forever."
"Couldn't you do something about it, Dumbledore?"

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: "ld, I wouldn't. Scars can come in handy. I have one myself above my left knee that is a perfect map of the London Underground."
"Well-- give him here, Hagrid -- we'd better get this over with."
"Could I -- could I say good-bye to him, sir?"
"Shhh!"
"You'll wake the Muggles!"
"S-s-sorry,"

scene.background: The Dursleys' house, with a small garden and a doorstep. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: "But I c-c-can't stand it -- Lily an' James dead-- an' poor little Harry off ter live with Muggles -"
"Yes, yes, it's all very sad, but get a grip on yourself, Hagrid, or we'll be found,"
"Well,"
"that's that. We've no business staying here. We may as well go and join the celebrations."
"Yeah,"
"I'll be takin' Sirius his bike back. G'night, Professor McGonagall -- Professor Dumbledore, sir."

scene.background: The street, with Hagrid's motorcycle and the night sky. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: "I shall see you soon, I expect, Professor McGonagall,"
"*blows nose in reply*"

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: "Privet Drive glowed suddenly orange and he could make out a tabby cat slinking around the corner at the other end of the street."
"Good luck, Harry."
"He turned on his heel and with a swish of his cloak, he was gone."
"A breeze ruffled the neat hedges of Privet Drive, which lay silent and tidy under the inky sky, the very last place you would expect astonishing things to happen."
"Harry Potter rolled over inside his blankets without waking up."

"One small hand closed on the letter beside him and he slept on, not knowing he was special, not knowing he was famous, not knowing he would be woken in a few hours' time by Mrs. Dursley's scream as she opened the front door to put out the milk bottles."

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: "Nearly ten years had passed since the Dursleys had woken up to find their nephew on the front step, but Privet Drive had hardly changed at all."
"The sun rose on the same tidy front gardens and lit up the brass number four on the Dursleys' front door."
"It crept into their living room, which was almost exactly the same as it had been on the night when Mr. Dursley had seen that fateful news report about the owls."
"Only the photographs on the mantelpiece really showed how much time had passed."

"Ten years ago, there had been lots of pictures of what looked like a large pink beach ball wearing different-colored bonnets -- but Dudley Dursley was no longer a baby, and now the photographs showed a large blond boy riding his first bicycle, on a carousel at the fair, playing a computer game with his father, being hugged and kissed by his mother."
"The room held no sign at all that another boy lived."

scene.background: A small, cluttered bedroom under the stairs, with a single bed and a cupboard full of spiders. The walls are drab and grey, with a small window high up that lets in a sliver of light. The atmosphere is cramped and oppressive.

dialogues.dialogue: Yet Harry Potter was still there, asleep at the moment, but not for long.
Up! Get up! Now!
Nearly...
Are you up yet?
What did you say?
I didn't hear what you said!

scene.background: A kitchen, with a table almost hidden beneath a pile of presents. The room is bright and cheerful, with a frying pan sizzling on the stove. The atmosphere is busy and chaotic.

dialogues.dialogue: I want you to look after the bacon. And don't you dare let it burn, I want everything perfect on Duddy's birthday.
Nothing, nothing...
Harry got slowly out of bed and started looking for socks.
He found a pair under his bed and, after pulling a spider off one of them, put them on.
Harry was used to spiders, because the cupboard under the stairs was full of them, and that was where he slept.
When he was dressed he went down the hall into the kitchen.

scene.background: A small, cluttered kitchen in the Dursleys' home, with a table in the center and a few chairs around it. The walls are a dull yellow, and the air is thick with the smell of cooking bacon.

dialogues.dialogue: Comb your hair!
About once a week, Uncle Vernon looked over the top of his newspaper and shouted that Harry needed a haircut.
Thirty-six. That's two less than last year.
Darling, you haven't counted Auntie Marge's present, see, it's here under this big one from Mommy and Daddy.
All right, thirty-seven then.
Harry, who could see a huge Dudley tantrum coming on, began wolfing down his bacon as fast as possible in case Dudley turned the table over.

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: While we're out today. How's that, popkin? Two more presents. Is that all right?
Thirty ... thirty...
Thirty-nine, sweetums.
Oh.
Little tyke wants his money's worth, just like his father. 'Atta boy, Dudley!
Bad news, Vernon. Mrs. Figg's broken her leg. She can't take him.
Now what?
We could phone Marge.
Don't be silly, Vernon, she hates the boy.
What about what's-her-name, your friend -- Yvonne?
On vacation in Majorca.
You could just leave me here.

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: hopefully (he'd be able to watch what he wanted on television for a change and maybe even have a go on Dudley's computer).
And come back and find the house in ruins?
I won't blow up the house,
I suppose we could take him to the zoo,
and leave him in the car....
That car's new, he's not sitting in it alone....

scene.background: The same living room, with Dudley now crying loudly.

dialogues.dialogue: Dinky Duddydums, don't cry, Mummy won't let him spoil your special day!
I... don't... want... him... t-t-to come!
He always sp- spoils everything!
Oh, good Lord, they're here!

scene.background: The same living room, with Piers and his mother entering.

dialogues.dialogue: Piers was a scrawny boy with a face like a rat.

scene.background: A moment later, with Uncle Vernon taking Harry aside.

dialogues.dialogue: I'm warning you,
I'm warning you now, boy -- any funny business, anything at all -- and you'll be in that cupboard from now until Christmas.
I'm not going to do anything,
honestly..

scene.background: The back of the Dursleys' car, with Harry, Piers, and Dudley on the way to the zoo.

dialogues.dialogue: Half an hour later, Harry, who couldn't believe his luck, was sitting in the back of the Dursleys' car with Piers and Dudley, on the way to the zoo for the first time in his life.

scene.background: A small, cluttered, and messy living room with old furniture and worn-out carpets. The atmosphere is tense and uncomfortable.

dialogues.dialogue: Once, Aunt Petunia, tired of Harry coming back from the barbers looking as though he hadn't been at all, had taken a pair of kitchen scissors and cut his hair so short he was almost bald except for his bangs, which she left "to hide that horrible scar."
I didn't make them happen!
You're lying, Harry! You're always making things happen!
Ha! Look at him, Mom! He's got a stupid haircut!
I didn't do it, Aunt Petunia! I swear!
Shut up, Harry! You're always causing trouble!

scene.background: A school kitchen with large pots and pans hanging from the ceiling. The atmosphere is chaotic and noisy.

dialogues.dialogue: Another time, Aunt Petunia had been trying to force him into a revolting old sweater of Dudley's (brown with orange puff balls) --
Harry, put this sweater on! It's nice and warm!
I don't want to, Aunt Petunia! It's ugly!
Yeah, Harry, you look stupid in that sweater!
I'm not wearing it!
Fine, be that way! You're so ungrateful!

scene.background: A school rooftop with chimneys and vents. The atmosphere is windy and exhilarating.

dialogues.dialogue: On the other hand, he'd gotten into terrible trouble for being found on the roof of the school kitchens.
I didn't climb up here! I was just trying to get away from Dudley!
You're lying, Harry! You're always getting into trouble!
I'm telling the truth, Uncle Vernon! I swear!
Yeah, Harry, you're always making up stories!
I'm not making it up! I didn't climb up here!

scene.background: A car interior with Uncle Vernon driving and Aunt Petunia sitting in the passenger seat. The atmosphere is tense and uncomfortable.

dialogues.dialogue: I'm telling you, Petunia, that boy is a menace!
Oh, Vernon, don't be so hard on him. He's just a boy.
A boy who makes things happen! A boy who's always getting into trouble!
Well, maybe he's just a bit... unusual.
Unusual? He's a freak, that's what he is!
I'm not a freak!

scene.background: A sunny Saturday morning at the zoo, with families walking around and children laughing. The atmosphere is lively and joyful, with the smell of ice cream and popcorn filling the air.

dialogues.dialogue: "... roaring along like maniacs, the young hoodlums."
"I had a dream about a motorcycle. It was flying."
"MOTORCYCLES DON'T FLY!"
"I know they don't. It was only a dream."
"What's wrong with the boy?"

scene.background: The zoo's restaurant, with families eating and chatting. The atmosphere is noisy and lively, with the smell of food and drinks filling the air.

dialogues.dialogue: "I don't want this knickerbocker glory! It doesn't have enough ice cream on top!"
"Here, have another one, Dudley."
"Thanks, Uncle Vernon."
"Why does he get to finish my ice cream?"
"Shh, Dudley, don't be ungrateful."

scene.background: The reptile house, with lit windows and dark surroundings. The atmosphere is cool and calm, with the sound of snakes and lizards crawling in the background.

dialogues.dialogue: "Wow, look at that snake."
"I don't want to look at snakes. They're boring."
"Yeah, let's go see the monkeys instead."
"Fine, let's go."
"I'll stay here for a bit."

scene.background: A reptile house in a zoo, with various tanks and enclosures containing snakes and other reptiles. The atmosphere is humid and slightly eerie, with the sound of hissing and rustling in the background.

dialogues.dialogue: Make it move.
*taps on the glass*
Do it again.
*raps on the glass*
This is boring.
*whispers* I know. It must be really annoying.
Where do you come from, anyway?

scene.background: The reptile house at the zoo, with various animals in their enclosures. The atmosphere is lively and noisy, with many visitors walking around.

dialogues.dialogue: DUDLEY! MR. DURSLEY! COME AND LOOK AT THIS SNAKE! YOU WON'T BELIEVE WHAT IT'S DOING!
Out of the way, you.
What came next happened so fast no one saw how it happened -- one second, Piers and Dudley were leaning right up close to the glass, the next, they had leapt back with howls of horror.
Brazil, here I come.... Thanksss, amigo.
But the glass, where did the glass go?
I'm so sorry, Aunt Petunia. Here, have a cup of strong, sweet tea.

scene.background: Uncle Vernon's car, with Piers, Dudley, and Harry sitting in the backseat. The atmosphere is tense and uncomfortable.

dialogues.dialogue: Harry was talking to it, weren't you, Harry?
It nearly bit off my leg!
It tried to squeeze me to death!
Go -- cupboard -- stay -- no meals.
Vernon, dear, have a large brandy.

scene.background: Harry's dark cupboard under the stairs, with a small amount of light peeking through the crack at the top. The atmosphere is dark and lonely.

dialogues.dialogue: Harry lay in his dark cupboard much later, wishing he had a watch.

scene.background: A small, dingy cupboard under the stairs, with old shoes and dusty boxes stacked around. The atmosphere is cramped and miserable.

dialogues.dialogue: "n years, ten miserable years, as long as he could remember, ever since he'd been a baby and his parents had died in that car crash."
"I couldn't remember being in the car when his parents had died."
"Sometimes, when he strained his memory during long hours in his cupboard, he came up with a strange vision: a blinding flash of green light and a burning pain on his forehead."
"This, he supposed, was the crash, though he couldn't imagine where all the green light came from."
"He couldn't remember his parents at all."

scene.background: Aunt Petunia's shopping street, with busy people walking by and shops lining the sidewalk. The atmosphere is ordinary and mundane.

dialogues.dialogue: "A tiny man in a violet top hat had bowed to him once while out shopping with Aunt Petunia and Dudley."
"Who was that man, Harry?"
"I don't know, Aunt Petunia."
"After asking Harry furiously if he knew the man, Aunt Petunia had rushed them out of the shop without buying anything."

scene.background: A bus, with people sitting and standing, holding onto handrails. The atmosphere is busy and noisy.

dialogues.dialogue: "A wild-looking old woman dressed all in green had waved merrily at him once on a bus."
"Who was that lady?"
"The weirdest thing about all these people was the way they seemed to vanish the second Harry tried to get a closer look."

scene.background: A street, with people walking by and buildings lining the sidewalk. The atmosphere is ordinary and mundane.

dialogues.dialogue: "A bald man in a very long purple coat had actually shaken his hand in the street the other day and then walked away without a word."
"Who was that man?"
"The weirdest thing about all these people was the way they seemed to vanish the second Harry tried to get a closer look."

scene.background: A school, with students sitting at desks and a teacher standing at the front. The atmosphere is dull and uninteresting.

dialogues.dialogue: "At school, Harry had no one."
"Everybody knew that Dudley's gang hated that odd Harry Potter in his baggy old clothes and broken glasses."
"Nobody liked to disagree with Dudley's gang."

scene.background: The Dursleys' home, with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: "The escape of the Brazilian boa constrictor earned Harry his longest-ever punishment."
"You're going to be punished, Harry."
"What did I do?"
"You let that snake escape."

scene.background: A street, with people walking by and buildings lining the sidewalk. The atmosphere is ordinary and mundane.

dialogues.dialogue: "By the time he was allowed out of his cupboard again, the summer holidays had started and Dudley had already broken his new video camera, crashed his remote control airplane, and, first time out on his racing bike, knocked down old Mrs. Figg."
"I'm going to ride my bike now."
"Oh no, not again!"

scene.background: A quiet suburban street, with neat gardens and tidy curtains. The houses are small and ordinary, with old-fashioned street lamps casting a warm glow. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: Harry was glad school was over, but there was no escaping Dudley's gang, who visited the house every single day.
Piers, Dennis, Malcolm, and Gordon were all big and stupid, but as Dudley was the biggest and stupidest of the lot, he was the leader.
No, thanks.
Want to come upstairs and practice?
The poor toilet's never had anything as horrible as your head down it -- it might be sick.

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort.

dialogues.dialogue: One day in July, Aunt Petunia took Dudley to London to buy his Smeltings uniform, leaving Harry at Mrs. Figg's.
Mrs. Figg wasn't as bad as usual. It turned out she'd broken her leg tripping over one of her cats,
Here, have a bit of chocolate cake that tasted as though I'd had it for several years.
Thanks.
That evening, Dudley paraded around the living room for the family in his brand-new uniform.

scene.background: A living room with a TV, armchairs, and a coffee table. The room is tidy and ordinary, with a hint of suburban comfort. Dudley is standing in his new uniform.

dialogues.dialogue: It's the proudest moment of my life.
Look at me!
Smeltings' boys wore maroon tailcoats, orange knickerbockers, and flat straw hats called boaters.
They stuff people's heads down the toilet the first day at Stonewall.
The poor toilet's never had anything as horrible as your head down it -- it might be sick.

scene.background: A small, cluttered kitchen with a sink, stove, and table. The atmosphere is tense and uncomfortable.

dialogues.dialogue: "Your new school uniform."
"Oh, I didn't realize it had to be so wet."
"Don't be stupid."
"Get the mail, Dudley."
"Make Harry get it."
"Make Dudley get it."

scene.background: The same kitchen, with the mail on the doormat. The atmosphere is still tense and uncomfortable.

dialogues.dialogue: "Poke him with your Smelting stick, Dudley."
(no dialogue, just a description of Harry dodging the Smelting stick)

scene.background: The same kitchen, with Harry holding the letter. The atmosphere is one of surprise and curiosity.

dialogues.dialogue: (no dialogue, just a description of Harry staring at the letter)

scene.background: The kitchen of the Dursleys' home, a small and ordinary room with a table, chairs, and a few appliances. The atmosphere is tense and unwelcoming.

dialogues.dialogue: Hurry up, boy! What are you doing, checking for letter bombs?
Marge's ill. Ate a funny whelk.
Dad! Dad, Harry's got something!
That's mine!
Who'd be writing to you?
Vernon! Oh my goodness -- Vernon!
I want to read that letter.

scene.background: The Dursleys' kitchen, a small and ordinary room with a table and chairs in the center. The atmosphere is tense and uncomfortable.

dialogues.dialogue: I want to read it! It's mine!
Get out, both of you!
I WANT MY LETTER!
Let me see it!
OUT!

scene.background: The Dursleys' kitchen, with the door closed and Harry and Dudley listening at the keyhole. The atmosphere is intense and secretive.

dialogues.dialogue: Vernon, look at the address -- how could they possibly know where he sleeps? You don't think they're watching the house?
Watching -- spying -- might be following us.
But what should we do, Vernon? Should we write back? Tell them we don't want --
No. No, we'll ignore it. If they don't get an answer... Yes, that's best... we won't do anything....

scene.background: Harry's cupboard, a small and cramped space with a single bed and a few belongings. The atmosphere is tense and confrontational.

dialogues.dialogue: Where's my letter? Who's writing to me?
No one. It was addressed to you by mistake.
It was not a mistake, it had my cupboard on it.
SILENCE!
Er -- yes, Harry -- about this cupboard. Your aunt and I have been thinking... you're really getting a bit big for it... we think it might be nice if you moved into Dudley's second bedroom.

scene.background: The Dursleys' house, a small and ordinary suburban home with a tidy garden and a quiet atmosphere.

dialogues.dialogue: Why?
Don't ask questions! Take this stuff upstairs, now.

scene.background: Harry's new room, cluttered with broken toys and objects, with a small bed in the center.

dialogues.dialogue: The month-old video camera was lying on top of a small, working tank Dudley had once driven over the next door neighbor's dog...
I don't want him in there... I need that room... make him get out...
Yesterday he'd have given anything to be up here. Today he'd rather be back in his cupboard with that letter than up here without it.

scene.background: The Dursleys' breakfast table, with a quiet and tense atmosphere.

dialogues.dialogue: Next morning at breakfast, everyone was rather quiet.
Dudley, go and get the mail.
There's anot...

scene.background: The smallest bedroom in number four, Privet Drive, with a small bed, a cupboard, and a desk. The room is small and cluttered, with a sense of confinement.

dialogues.dialogue: With a strangled cry, Uncle Vernon leapt from his seat and ran down the hall, Harry right behind him.
Go to your cupboard -- I mean, your bedroom.
Dudley -- go -- just go.

scene.background: The same small bedroom, with Harry pacing around the room, looking anxious and determined.

dialogues.dialogue: Harry walked round and round his new room. Someone knew he had moved out of his cupboard and they seemed to know he hadn't received his first letter. Surely that meant they'd try again? And this time he'd make sure they didn't fail. He had a plan.

scene.background: The dark hallway of number four, Privet Drive, with the front door at the end. The atmosphere is tense and secretive.

dialogues.dialogue: He stole downstairs without turning on any of the lights.
Ah!

scene.background: The same dark hallway, with Uncle Vernon lying on the floor in a sleeping bag, looking angry and menacing.

dialogues.dialogue: [shouting at Harry for about half an hour]
Now, go and make a cup of tea.

scene.background: The kitchen of number four, Privet Drive, with Uncle Vernon sitting at the table, surrounded by letters. The atmosphere is tense and confrontational.

dialogues.dialogue: I want --
[tearing the letters into pieces before Harry's eyes]

scene.background: A small, ordinary suburban house with a neat garden and tidy curtains. The atmosphere is quiet and suburban.

dialogues.dialogue: "See,"
"if they can't deliver them they'll just give up."
"I'm not sure that'll work, Vernon."
"Oh, these people's minds work in strange ways, Petunia, they're not like you and me,"

scene.background: The same suburban house, but with a flurry of letters scattered around the front door and living room.

dialogues.dialogue: "On Friday, no less than twelve letters arrived for Harry."
"Tiptoe Through the Tulips"

scene.background: The same suburban house, but with the milkman handing Aunt Petunia eggs through the living room window.

dialogues.dialogue: "Who on earth wants to talk to you this badly?"
"I'll get to the bottom of this!"

scene.background: The same suburban house, but with the kitchen in disarray and letters scattered everywhere.

dialogues.dialogue: "No post on Sundays,"
"no damn letters today --"
"OUT! OUT!"
"Wait!"

scene.background: The interior of the Dursleys' home, with letters streaming in through the door and bouncing off the walls and floor. The atmosphere is chaotic and frantic.

dialogues.dialogue: "That does it,"
"I want you all back here in five minutes ready to leave. We're going away. Just pack some clothes. No arguments!"

scene.background: The interior of the Dursleys' car, speeding down the highway. The atmosphere is tense and anxious.

dialogues.dialogue: "Shake 'em off... shake 'em off,"

scene.background: A gloomy-looking hotel on the outskirts of a big city. The atmosphere is dull and unwelcoming.

dialogues.dialogue: They didn't stop to eat or drink all day.

scene.background: A hotel room with twin beds and damp, musty sheets. The atmosphere is dull and uncomfortable.

dialogues.dialogue: Dudley snored but Harry stayed awake, sitting on the windowsill, staring down at the lights of passing cars and wondering....

scene.background: A hotel dining room, with the Dursleys eating stale cornflakes and cold tinned tomatoes on toast for breakfast. The atmosphere is dull and unappetizing.

dialogues.dialogue: They had just finished when the owner of the hotel came over to their table.
'Scuse me, but is one of you Mr. H. Potter?
